Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Effect of Sea Level Variation of Fuelwood Sustainability

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Mangroves have long been important to meet the fuelwood needs of people living along tropical coastlines. In turn, mangrove forests are critically important to coastal ecosystem health. This project examines long-term mangrove forest composition based on data collected from archaeological wood samples from South Florida. It makes use of fuelwood residues, a rarely exploited data source, to investigate wood selection and management strategies along with their secondary effects on local forests. A key question being addressed is resource sustainability, as evidenced in changing wood availability. Moreover, the time-transgressive trends in wood species and their growth cycles documented by this research will help to establish a long-term record of forest health and resilience that can be used not only to contextualize the magnitude of recent and ongoing changes, but to aid in understanding legacy effects from activities such as thinning and habitat reduction, as well as from natural disasters (e.g., hurricanes) and environmental change. Although coastal forests have long been recognized as providing valuable ecological services, they are endangered worldwide. The importance of coastal mangrove communities to tropical coastal and marine environments and thus also, to human inhabitants and local economies is difficult to exaggerate. These forests provide habitat and breeding grounds for many marine organisms, thus supporting several fisheries. Mangrove forests buffer coastlines against hurricanes and inhibit terrestrial runoff further contributing to ecosystem health and protection. The use of archaeological wood charcoal to establish an historical timeline of mangrove forest presence and growth characteristics will provide a valuable context for establishing modern management guidelines and regulations. To that end, this project is working in concert with local conservation organizations and state agencies; each will benefit through cooperation and data sharing. Furthermore, the research contributes to the education and training of both graduate and undergraduate students, as well as local residents and project volunteers.

One aspect of the research is testing alternative hypotheses generated from prior study of proxy records of sea-level variability over time. Sea level and water quality have direct effects on the survival and biogeography of mangrove communities. While this project is focused primarily on Calusa Island, the work is part of a larger endeavor that examines ancient human-forest resource interactions regionally. The wood charcoal analyzed here derives from an eroding archaeological shell mound and will aid in the creation of a long-term baseline of forest resilience as influenced by human activity, natural disturbances, and climate change in Southwest Florida's coastal estuary system. The research will also initiate an archaeological site monitoring project that will track rates of shoreline erosion and impacts on both the archaeological deposits and the modern forest/flora. Further, the exploratory excavations will aid in documenting a regionally, rare Archaic Period occupation and will provide preliminary data that will enable future conservation work or salvage excavations at the site. Finally, this project will collect exploratory pollen data to evaluate their potential for use as an independent environmental proxy on the influence of high-intensity, natural disturbance events, such as hurricanes, among the mangroves.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mangroves have long been important to meet the fuelwood needs of people living along tropical coastlines. In turn, mangrove forests are critically important to coastal ecosystem health. This project is part of a larger endeavor to examine long-term change in mangrove forest composition based on data collected from archaeological wood samples from South Florida. We make use of fuelwood residues, a rarely exploited data source, to investigate wood selection and management strategies along with their secondary effects on local forests. A key question being addressed is resource sustainability, as evidenced in changing wood availability. Although coastal forests have long been recognized as providing valuable ecological services, they are endangered worldwide. The importance of coastal mangrove communities to tropical coastal and marine environments and thus also, to human inhabitants and local economies is difficult to exaggerate. These forests provide habitat and breeding grounds for many marine organisms, thus supporting several fisheries. Mangrove forests buffer coastlines against hurricanes and inhibit terrestrial runoff further contributing to ecosystem health and protection. The use of archaeological wood charcoal to establish an historical timeline of mangrove forest presence and growth characteristics provides a valuable context for establishing modern management guidelines and regulations. To that end, our project works in concert with local conservation organizations and state agencies; each benefiting through cooperation and data sharing. Furthermore, the research contributed to the education and training of both graduate and undergraduate students, as well as local residents and project volunteers.   

Shoreline monitoring was established to determine the rate and season of erosion occurring on the beach. With the shoreline constantly shifting, the mangroves struggle to keep pace and establish prior to inundation. We now estimate that an erosion rate of approximately 1 foot per year is fast enough to prevent mangroves from establishing along the beach. Also, the site is experiencing a significant amount of erosion/impact during the ‘dry’ (winter) season. This winter season erosion is undercutting the high elevation midden wall and impacting the lower elevations, extending the wrack line at the site. The winter season erosion likely results more from waves/tides (i.e., sea level changes) than intense, storm-derived rains – counter to expectations.

Several significant results were produced during the archaeological testing of Calusa Island, Lee County, Florida. Additional radiometric dating of the site deposits indicated that some of the upper levels had been secondarily deposited atop the midden from elsewhere on site. The secondary nature of these deposits hampered the collection of wood anatomical data sought because the recovery of wood charcoal was sparse and the individual specimens were very small. Nevertheless, much of the wood charcoal recovered could be identified to taxa and represented not only the predominant local woods (pine, red mangrove, and black mangrove) but also white mangrove, buttonwood, and live oak. These secondary wood types are also local but were used less frequently for fuel. It should be remembered that sample sizes were small but suggested that the diversity of fuelwood used at Calusa Island during the late Archaic may have been greater than seen at similar earlier sites, such as Useppa Island and Horr’s Island. In particular, white mangrove quickly colonizes forest gaps following storms and the recovery of white mangrove within the small sample may indicate that the site was inhabited during a time of increased storm activity. Additionally, several living surfaces may be present within the midden deposits based on artifact size/condition, organic content, wood charcoal, and pollen samples. Further testing would be needed to confirm these functional assignments. Since the work at Calusa Island is only a portion of a larger investigation of the impacts of past sea level fluctuations, data analysis is ongoing and the suppositions proposed here are being tested further elsewhere with additional data sets.

Calusa Island is important to local and regional archaeology because it was inhabited during the late Archaic and relatively few additional sites have been found to date from this period. The site is currently experiencing heavy erosion along its northern shore and without continued archaeological work, we cannot know the age and potential importance of the lost deposits. The work conducted here was a small step toward understanding the late Archaic environment at Calusa Island and what those deposits can tell us about what may happen as sea level continues to rise in modern times in South Florida.
